column4:
Sanders, Debbie A.
Mukhari, Shirley S.
column5: Lecturers' perceptions of the influence of AI on a blended learning approach in a South African higher education institution.
column6: This study explores lecturers' perspectives on the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on blended learning within South African higher education. It examines how AI integration influences teaching practices and the challenges faced during implementation.
column7: The research was conducted in a South African higher education institution, focusing on lecturers' experiences with AI in blended learning environments.
column8: A qualitative case study approach was employed, involving semi-structured focus group interviews with 15 lecturers from the College of Education. Document analysis of course materials and teaching methods complemented the interviews.
column9: The study's findings are based on a single institution and a limited sample size, which may affect the generalizability of the results.
column10: Successful AI integration in blended learning requires robust management support, enhanced training opportunities, reliable technological infrastructure, and sufficient time allocation for lecturers.
column11: Sanders, D. A., & Mukhari, S. S. (2024). Lecturers’ perceptions of the influence of AI on a blended learning approach in a South African higher education institution. Discover Education, 3(1), 1–18. https://doi-org.libproxy.nie.edu.sg/10.1007/s44217-024-00235-2

column4: Jim Marquardson

column7: Capstone cybersecurity course focusing on AI-assisted learning.
column8: Practical application with student feedback and outcome analysis.
column9: Limited to a single course and specific AI tool.
column10: AI tools enhance self-directed learning when students are well-trained.

column5: Academic Integrity in the Age of Generative AI: Perceptions and Responses of Vietnamese EFL Teachers
column6: This study examines Vietnamese EFL teachers' perceptions and responses to academic integrity challenges posed by generative AI tools like ChatGPT. It identifies causes of AI-based plagiarism and suggests pedagogical strategies to address these issues.
column7: Vietnamese higher education, focusing on English as a Foreign Language (EFL) instruction.
column8: Open-ended survey of 31 Vietnamese EFL teachers.
column9: Small sample size and focus on a specific educational context may limit generalizability.
column10: Teachers attribute AI-driven plagiarism to a lack of original ideas and poor learning attitudes. They advocate for increased regulations, AI-based plagiarism detectors, and education on responsible AI use.
column11: Cong-Lem, N., Tran, T. N., & Nguyen, T. T. (2024). Academic integrity in the age of generative AI: Perceptions and responses of Vietnamese EFL teachers. Teaching English With Technology, 2024(1). https://doi.org/10.56297/fsyb3031/mxnb7567

column4: Maanak Gupta, Charankumar Akiri, K. Aryal, Elisabeth Parker, Lopamudra Praharaj
column5: From ChatGPT to ThreatGPT: Impact of Generative AI in Cybersecurity and Privacy
column6: Analyzes the dual role of Generative AI (GenAI) in cybersecurity, highlighting its potential for both enhancing defenses and facilitating cyberattacks. The study examines vulnerabilities in models like ChatGPT, including susceptibility to jailbreaks and prompt injection attacks, and discusses how adversaries might exploit GenAI for social engineering, phishing, and malware creation. It also explores defensive applications, such as automated threat detection and secure code generation, while addressing the social, legal, and ethical implications of GenAI in cybersecurity.
column7: Cybersecurity landscape in the United States.
column8: Comprehensive review of GenAI applications in cybersecurity, supported by case studies and theoretical analysis.
column9: Primarily theoretical; lacks empirical validation.
column10: GenAI presents both opportunities and risks in cybersecurity, necessitating robust ethical guidelines and adaptive defense strategies.
column11: Gupta, M., Akiri, C., Aryal, K., Parker, E., & Praharaj, L. (2023). From ChatGPT to ThreatGPT: Impact of Generative AI in Cybersecurity and Privacy. IEEE Access, 11, 80218-80245. https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2023.3300381.

column4: Jie Li, Hancheng Cao, Laura Lin, Youyang Hou, Ruihao Zhu, Abdallah El Ali
column5: User Experience Design Professionals' Perceptions of Generative Artificial Intelligence
column6: Investigates how User Experience (UX) designers perceive Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) and its impact on their practice. Through interviews with 20 UX designers from various companies, the study reveals that experienced designers view GenAI as an assistive tool, emphasizing the importance of human creativity and empathy. However, concerns are raised about potential skill degradation and job displacement among junior designers. The research discusses implications for human-GenAI collaboration, including issues of copyright, creativity, and AI literacy.
column7: UX design professionals in the United States.
column8: Conducted interviews with 20 UX designers across startups and large enterprises to gather qualitative insights.
column9: Limited sample size and geographic focus may affect the generalizability of the findings.
column10: Experienced designers view GenAI as a supportive tool, while junior designers express concerns about skill erosion and job security.
column11: Li, J., Cao, H., Lin, L., Hou, Y., Zhu, R., & Ali, A. (2023). User Experience Design Professionals' Perceptions of Generative Artificial Intelligence. ArXiv, abs/2309.15237. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2309.15237.

column4: Hazel Farrell
column5: Pseudo-Research: A Fabricated Study on Student Engagement in Music Pedagogy
column6: This article presents a fabricated study on student engagement in music pedagogy, created using ChatGPT. It aims to highlight the potential misuse of AI in generating pseudo-research and discusses the implications for academic integrity.
column7: The study is set within the realm of music education, focusing on the ethical considerations of AI-generated content in academic research.
column8: The author utilized ChatGPT to generate a fictitious research article, then analyzed the process and outcomes to discuss the ethical implications.
column9: As a fabricated study, the findings are not based on empirical data and serve solely to illustrate the potential for AI misuse.
column10: The article underscores the necessity for stringent ethical guidelines and critical evaluation of AI-generated content to maintain academic integrity.
column11: Farrell, H. (2023). Pseudo-Research: A Fabricated Study on Student Engagement in Music Pedagogy. Irish Journal of Technology Enhanced Learning. https://doi.org/10.22554/ijtel.v7i2.145.

column4: J. Prather, Paul Denny, Juho Leinonen, Brett A. Becker, Ibrahim Albluwi, Michelle Craig, H. Keuning, Natalie Kiesler, Tobias Kohn, Andrew Luxton-Reilly, Stephen MacNeil, Andrew Petersen, Raymond Pettit, Brent N. Reeves, Jaromír Šavelka
column5: The Robots Are Here: Navigating the Generative AI Revolution in Computing Education
column6: This comprehensive study examines the impact of generative AI, particularly large language models (LLMs), on computing education. It synthesizes findings from 71 primary articles, surveys computing students and instructors across 20 countries, and includes interviews with 22 educators from five continents. The report discusses ethical considerations using the ACM Code of Ethics and benchmarks current GenAI models on educational datasets.
column7: Global computing education.
column8: Literature review, international surveys, educator interviews, ethical analysis, and model benchmarking.
column9: Rapidly evolving field; findings may become outdated as technology advances.
column10: Generative AI is poised to significantly influence computing education, necessitating adaptive pedagogical strategies and ethical guidelines.

column4:
Cheng, Ying
Boyraz, Maggie
Taylor, Julie L.
Gilbert, Rosemarie
column5: Investigation College Students' and Instructors' Perspectives on Adopting Technologies for Public Speaking Skills Development in a Hispanic Serving University
column6: This study examines the adoption of technologies aimed at enhancing public speaking skills among college students and instructors at a Hispanic-Serving Institution. It explores the relationship between students' communication competence, their perceptions of technology features, satisfaction with these technologies, and their intention to use them. Additionally, it gathers instructors' insights on incorporating such technologies into their teaching practices.
column7: Higher education at a Hispanic-Serving Institution in the United States.
column8: The research employs a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative surveys of students (n = 80) and qualitative surveys of instructors (n = 11).
column9: The study is limited by its focus on a single institution, which may affect the generalizability of the findings.
column10: Students with lower communication competence perceive public speaking technologies as more useful. Their perceived usefulness and ease of use are positively associated with future intentions to use these technologies, mediated by their satisfaction. Instructors find these technologies helpful when they assist rather than replace human feedback.
column11: Cheng, Y., Boyraz, M., Taylor, J. L., & Gilbert, R. (2023). Investigation College Students’ and Instructors’ Perspectives on Adopting Technologies for Public Speaking Skills Development in a Hispanic Serving University. International Journal of Education and Development Using Information and Communication Technology, 19(1), 80–101.

column5: Utilizing AI Models to Optimize Blended Teaching Effectiveness in College-Level English Education
column6: This study explores the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into blended learning for college-level English education. It proposes models utilizing deep learning and human job functions to enhance teaching effectiveness. The research highlights the potential of AI technologies, such as cloud computing and big data, to transform educational practices and improve student outcomes.
column7: Higher education institutions in China.
column8: The study employs a theoretical approach, developing models based on multi-modal blended learning theory and independent learning fundamentals.
column9: The research is primarily theoretical and lacks empirical validation through practical implementation.
column10: Integrating AI into blended learning can significantly enhance the quality of college English education by supporting student learning and optimizing teaching strategies.

column5: Stakeholder Perspectives on the Ethics of AI in Distance-Based Higher Education
column6: This study explores the ethical considerations of integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into distance-based higher education. Through interviews with 18 stakeholders—including students, educators, and administrators—the research identifies key ethical concerns such as data privacy, algorithmic bias, and the transparency of AI systems. The findings emphasize the necessity for clear ethical guidelines and policies to ensure responsible AI implementation in educational settings.
column7: Distance-based higher education institutions in the United Kingdom.
column8: Qualitative interviews with 18 stakeholders involved in distance education.
column9: The study's focus on a specific educational context may limit the generalizability of its findings.
column10: Stakeholders express significant ethical concerns regarding AI in education, highlighting the need for transparent and fair AI practices.
column11: Holmes, W., Iniesto, F., Anastopoulou, S., & Boticario, J. G. (2023). Stakeholder perspectives on the ethics of AI in distance-based Higher Education. The International Review of Research in Open and Distributed Learning, 24(2), 96–117. https://doi.org/10.19173/irrodl.v24i2.6089

column4: Rosemary Luckin, Mutlu Cukurova, Carmel Kent, Benedict du Boulay
column5: Empowering educators to be AI-ready
column6: This article discusses the necessity for educators to develop AI literacy to effectively integrate artificial intelligence into teaching and learning. It outlines a framework for AI readiness, emphasizing understanding AI concepts, ethical considerations, and practical applications in education. The authors advocate for professional development programs to equip teachers with the skills needed to navigate the evolving educational landscape influenced by AI technologies.
column7: Educational institutions in the United Kingdom.
column8: The study employs a theoretical approach, proposing a framework based on existing literature and expert insights.
column9: The framework is conceptual and requires empirical validation through practical implementation.
column10: Educators must attain AI literacy to harness AI's potential in education effectively, necessitating targeted professional development initiatives.
column11: Luckin, R., Cukurova, M., Kent, C., & du Boulay, B. (2022). Empowering educators to be AI-ready. Computers and Education: Artificial Intelligence, 3, 100076. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.caeai.2022.100076

column4:
Schroeder, Kersten T.
Hubertz, Martha
Van Campenhout, Rachel
Johnson, Benny G.
column5: Teaching and Learning with AI-Generated Courseware: Lessons from the Classroom
column6: This study examines the implementation of AI-generated courseware in two university courses, focusing on its impact on student engagement and learning outcomes. The authors discuss the selection and enhancement of AI-generated materials, instructor practices over multiple semesters, and the resulting effects on student performance. The findings suggest that adaptive courseware can benefit both students and instructors by improving engagement and facilitating iterative teaching improvements.
column7: Higher education courses at the University of Central Florida.
column8: Case study analysis of two courses utilizing AI-generated courseware, including qualitative assessments of instructor practices and quantitative measures of student engagement and exam scores.
column9: The study is limited to two specific courses at a single institution, which may affect the generalizability of the findings.
column10: The use of AI-generated courseware can enhance student engagement and learning outcomes when effectively integrated into course design and instruction.
column11: Schroeder, K. T., Hubertz, M., Van Campenhout, R., & Johnson, B. G. (2022). Teaching and learning with AI-generated courseware: Lessons from the classroom. Online Learning, 26(3). https://doi.org/10.24059/olj.v26i3.3370

column4:
Youmei Wang
Chenchen Liu
Yun-Fang Tu
column5: Factors Affecting the Adoption of AI-Based Applications in Higher Education: An Analysis of Teachers' Perspectives Using Structural Equation Modeling.
column6: This study investigates factors influencing Chinese university teachers' adoption of AI-based applications in higher education. Utilizing structural equation modeling, the research examines variables such as perceived usefulness, perceived ease of use, and facilitating conditions. Findings indicate that perceived usefulness significantly impacts teachers' intentions to use AI applications, while perceived ease of use and facilitating conditions also play crucial roles. The study suggests that enhancing teachers' perceptions of AI's benefits and providing adequate support can promote AI adoption in educational settings.
column7: Higher education institutions in China.
column8: Surveyed 300 university teachers; analyzed data using structural equation modeling.
column9: Focuses on Chinese educators; results may not generalize globally.
column10: Perceived usefulness, ease of use, and facilitating conditions significantly influence teachers' adoption of AI-based applications.
column11: Youmei Wang, Chenchen Liu, & Yun-Fang Tu. (2021). Factors Affecting the Adoption of AI-Based Applications in Higher Education: An Analysis of Teachers’ Perspectives Using Structural Equation Modeling. Educational Technology & Society, 24(3), 116–129.

column4: Michael Wollowski, Robert Selkowitz, Laura E. Brown, Ashok Goel, George Luger, Jim Marshall ,Andrew Neel, Todd Neller,Peter Norvig
column5: A Survey of Current Practice and Teaching of AI
column6: This study examines the current practices in teaching artificial intelligence (AI) by surveying educators and practitioners. It identifies prevalent topics, teaching methodologies, and the alignment between academic instruction and industry requirements. The findings highlight a need for curriculum updates to incorporate modern AI developments and suggest enhancing collaboration between academia and industry to better prepare students for professional roles.
column7: AI education in the United States.
column8: Conducted surveys among AI educators and practitioners to gather data on teaching practices and industry expectations.
column9: The study's focus on U.S.-based respondents may limit the applicability of its conclusions to other regions.
column10: There is a discrepancy between academic AI curricula and industry needs, indicating a necessity for curriculum enhancements and stronger academia-industry partnerships.
column11: Wollowski, M., Selkowitz, R., Brown, L., Goel, A., Luger, G., Marshall, J., Neel, A., Neller, T., & Norvig, P. (2016). A survey of current practice and teaching of ai. Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, 30(1). https://doi.org/10.1609/aaai.v30i1.9857

column4: Wang Xinghua
column5: Preparing for AI-enhanced education: Conceptualizing and empirically examining teachers’ AI readiness
column6: Introduces the concept of teachers' AI readiness, measuring awareness, knowledge, and ability, and examines its relationship with TPACK.
column7: Primary and secondary education in China.
column8: Survey of 1,012 teachers; confirmatory factor analysis and structural equation modeling.
column9: Focus on Chinese educators; limited generalizability.
column10: AI readiness is distinct from TPACK and crucial for effective AI integration in teaching.
column11: Wang, X., Li, L., Tan, S. C., Yang, L., & Lei, J. (2023). Preparing for AI-Enhanced Education: Conceptualizing and empirically examining teachers’ ai readiness. Computers in Human Behavior, 146, 107798. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chb.2023.107798

column4:
Genimon Vadakkemulanjanal Joseph 
P. Athira 
M. Anit Thomas
Dawn Jose 
Therese V. Roy 
Malavika Prasad
column5: Impact of Digital Literacy, Use of AI Tools and Peer Collaboration on AI Assisted Learning: Perceptions of the University Students
column6: This study investigates how digital literacy, the use of AI tools, and peer-supported collaborative learning (PSCL) influence university students' perceptions of AI-assisted learning. Surveying 409 students, the research reveals positive correlations among these factors. Notably, PSCL and AI tool usage partially mediate the relationship between digital literacy and AI-assisted learning perceptions, suggesting that enhancing digital literacy and fostering collaborative learning can improve students' engagement with AI in education.
column7: University students in India.
column8: Descriptive research using structured questionnaires, analyzed with SPSS, Excel, and Process Macro.
column9: Focused on a specific demographic; results may not generalize broadly.
column10: Digital literacy, peer collaboration, and AI tool usage enhance students' perceptions of AI-assisted learning.
column11: Genimon Vadakkemulanjanal Joseph, P. Athira, M. Anit Thomas, Dawn Jose, Therese V. Roy, & Malavika Prasad. (2024). Impact of Digital Literacy, Use of AI Tools and Peer Collaboration on AI Assisted Learning: Perceptions of the University Students. Digital Education Review, 45, 43–49.

column4:
Sheri Grotrian
Lisa Parriott
Brad Griffin
Brady Woerth
Wyatt Rowell
column5: Student Perceptions of ChatGPT and New AI Tools
column6: Explores college students' perceptions of ChatGPT and other AI tools in academic settings. The study reveals students recognize the benefits of AI tools for learning and efficiency but express concerns about academic integrity and ethical implications.
column7: Higher education institutions in the United States.
column8: Survey-based research collecting quantitative and qualitative data from students.
column9: Focused on a specific demographic, limiting generalizability.
column10: Students acknowledge both the advantages and ethical challenges of using AI tools like ChatGPT in academics.
column11: Sheri Grotrian, Lisa Parriott, Brad Griffin, Brady Woerth, & Wyatt Rowell. (2024). Student Perceptions of ChatGPT and New AI Tools. Educational Research: Theory and Practice, 35(2), 27–30.

column4:
Dongmin Ma
Huma Akram
I-Hua Chen
column5: Artificial Intelligence in Higher Education: A Cross- Cultural Examination of Students’ Behavioral Intentions and Attitudes.
column6: This study examines the differences in attitudes and behavioral intentions toward artificial intelligence (AI) between Chinese and international university students. Utilizing the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), the research collected data through questionnaires and analyzed it using structural equation modeling and descriptive statistics. The findings reveal significant disparities in AI usage prevalence, attitudes, and behavioral intentions between the two groups. Notably, perceived ease of use had a more substantial impact on both attitudes and behavioral intentions among international students compared to their Chinese counterparts. The study underscores the importance of considering cultural backgrounds and prior technological exposure when integrating AI into higher education. It advocates for tailored educational strategies that address diverse cultural perspectives, provide language-specific support, and ensure user-friendly interfaces to optimize AI adoption in pedagogical practices.
column7: Higher education institutions in China, involving both domestic and international students.
column8: Survey-based data collection from Chinese and international students; analysis conducted using structural equation modeling and descriptive statistics.
column9: The study focuses on a specific educational context within China, which may limit the generalizability of the findings to other cultural or institutional settings.
column10: Cultural backgrounds and prior technological exposure significantly influence students' attitudes and behavioral intentions toward AI, with international students showing a stronger relationship between perceived ease of use and their attitudes and intentions compared to Chinese students.
column11: Dongmin Ma, Huma Akram, & I-Hua Chen. (2024). Artificial Intelligence in Higher Education: A Cross- Cultural Examination of Students’ Behavioral Intentions and Attitudes. International Review of Research in Open & Distributed Learning, 25(3), 134–157. https://doi-org.libproxy.nie.edu.sg/10.19173/irrodl.v25i3.7703

column6: Explores how AI versus human grading impacts students' fairness perceptions. AI is seen as fairer due to transparency, but explanations reduce differences.

column9: Focused on Chinese students; limited global applicability.

column10: Students found the chatbot improved learning and understanding.

column5: University students' intentions to learn artificial intelligence: the roles of supportive environments and expectancy–value beliefs.
column6: This study examines how supportive environments and expectancy–value beliefs influence university students' intentions to learn AI. Data from 494 students indicate that both factors significantly enhance students' motivation to engage with AI learning.
column7: University students across various disciplines.
column8: Structural equation modeling and latent profile analysis.
column9: Specific demographic focus may limit generalizability.
column10: Supportive environments and positive expectancy–value beliefs are crucial in fostering AI learning intentions.

column5: CREATIVITY AND GENERATIVE AI IN EDUCATIONAL CONTEXTS: CHALLENGES AND FUTURE SCENARIOS. SURVEY ON THE PERCEPTIONS OF STUDENTS AND TEACHERS.
column6: This study examines the interplay between human creativity and generative AI in educational settings. Through a survey of secondary school teachers and university students in educational sciences, it explores the opportunities and challenges of integrating AI systems into education. Findings highlight the potential of AI to enhance creative processes while also presenting ethical and practical challenges.
column7: Secondary and higher education institutions in Italy
column8: Survey of teachers and university students.
column9: Focuses on specific educational levels within Italy; results may not generalize globally.
column10: AI can augment creativity in education but requires careful consideration of ethical and practical implications.
column11: Treglia, E., & Tomassoni, R. (2024). Creativity and Generative Ai in Educational Contexts: Challenges and Future Scenarios. Survey on the Perceptions of Students and Teachers. Italian Journal of Health Education, Sport & Inclusive Didactics, 8(2), 388–401. https://doi-org.libproxy.nie.edu.sg/10.32043/gsd.v8i2.1147
